text:
Foreign-owned Caterpillar UK remains committed to Britain despite Brexit result X 
Copy link to paste in your message / Comments (0) 
Caterpillar UK has said it remains committed to the country despite the vote to leave the EU. 
The digger manufacturer, which is owned by Caterpillar Inc, of Illinois, employs around 1,500 people in Desford and supplies to customers all over the world. 
Mark Dorsett, Caterpillar UK country director said that the company acknowledges and respects the decision made by the British people for the UK to leave the European Union. Read more: UK votes to leave European Union with Leicestershire overwhelmingly backing Brexit - LIVE 
He said: "As a global manufacturer with a large footprint in the UK and across Europe, we call on the British government and its European partners to make all efforts to move forward swiftly to negotiate a new settlement. 
"The UK is an intrinsic part of our European supply chain and we urge all parties to reach an agreement that quickly removes the uncertainty, allows the UK to retain full access to and from the single market and protects the interests of businesses with strong commitments and investments in the UK. "We acknowledge the complexities involved and recognise that the process to leave could take time. We urge that the single market access issues be prioritized to lessen the negative impact on business and on both the UK and European economies. "Caterpillar remains committed to a competitive presence in the UK and will diligently look at ways to mitigate the impact of the UK's decision to leave the EU on our valued customers, employees, shareholders and partners in our integrated supply chain." 
Read more: EU referendum result: How did Leicester, Leicestershire and Rutland vote? 
Earlier this morning, the pound slumped to to a 31-year low on currency markets after the result was announced. 
Bank of England governor Mark Carney said that will make Â£250bn of additional funds available through its normal market operations to stability markets, as needed. 
Carolyn Fairbairn, CBI director general, said : "The British people's vote to leave the EU is a momentous turning point in our history. The country has spoken and it's for us all to listen. 
"Many businesses will be concerned and need time to assess the implications. But they are used to dealing with challenge and change and we should be confident they will adapt. 
"The urgent priority now is to reassure the markets. We need strong and calm leadership from the Government, working with the Bank of England, to shore up confidence and stability in the economy. 
"The choices we make over the coming months will affect generations to come. This is not a time for rushed decisions. 
"The CBI will be consulting its members and business is committed to working with Government to shape the best possible conditions for future prosperity."
